items.title: Afternoon Update: Australia’s climate breakdown risks laid bare; ANZ slapped with record fine; and Adolescence wins big at Emmys
items.standfirst: Want to get this in your inbox every weekday? Sign up for the Afternoon Update here, and start your day with our Morning Mail newsletter.Good afternoon. The climate change minister, Chris Bowen, has mounted the case for the federal government to set a strong 2035 emissions reduction target after releasing a “confronting” report which provided the most detailed picture of the severe and far-reaching social and economic consequences of the climate crisis for Australia.The long-awaited national climate risk assessment found the number of heat-related deaths in Sydney could surge by almost 450% if global heating surpasses 3C, with no Australian community immune from the “cascading, compounding and concurrent” risks of a worsening climate.Complaint letter emerges after Melbourne hospital’s decision to cancel ‘children and war’ panel angers staff‘Betrayed the trust of Australians’: ANZ bank pays record $240m fine for widespread misconductEmma Lovell murder: Queensland to appeal to high court for harsher sentence for teen killerAFL confirms State of Origin football to return in 2026 after 27-year hiatusGout Gout says he is ‘ready to rumble’ ahead of World Athletics Championships debutTrump insists foreign workers are ‘welcome’ days after arrest of hundreds of South Koreans Continue reading...

items.title: Landmark climate report shows 'every Australian has a lot at stake', minister says – video
items.standfirst: Chris Bowen, the climate change minister, held a press conference after the release of a new report that finds no Australian community would be immune from the risks of worsening climate change. 'One thing that is very clear from this climate assessment is that the whole country has a lot at stake. Every Australian, regardless of where they live, has a lot at stake,' said Bowen. The long-awaited national climate risk assessment provides the most detailed picture of the severe and far-reaching social and economic impact of the climate crisis for Australia.► Subscribe to Guardian Australia on YouTubeMillions of Australians at risk from rising sea levels and heat deaths could soar, landmark climate report warns Continue reading...

items.title: Heatwave deaths to soar, 1.5 million Aussies at risk of flooding
items.standfirst: Australia's first climate risk assessment released today has detailed some of the biggest natural threats facing the nation as the global average temperature ramps up.
items.content: Around 1.5 million Australians will be at risk of sea level rise by 2050, according to a dire inaugural climate risk assessment.Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA), released today, has detailed some of the biggest natural threats facing the nation as the global average temperature ramps up.The report found even just 1.5 degrees of warming would raise sea levels by 0.14 metres.READ MORE: 'Note' left by Charlie Kirk shooting suspect under investigation"By 2050, the number of coastal communities located in high and very-high risk areas will increase from 8 per cent to 18 per cent due to sea level rise," the report states."If current populations remained as they are today, this would represent an increase to 1.5 million people at risk."The assessment also noted that 34 per cent of coastal communities could be at risk by 2090 – a total of three million Australians.READ MORE: These siblings started a business with a few hundred bucks. It's made $20 millionThe report looked at three key warming scenarios in Australia: 1.5 degrees, 2 degrees and three degrees of warming.It found the planet is heading towards 2.9 degrees of warming by 2030.Warming of this level would result in heatwave deaths skyrocketing by 444 per cent in Sydney and 423 per cent in Darwin.READ MORE: Teacher who beat cancer killed in tragic jet ski accidentThe rising temperatures will then increase the risk of communicable diseases from mosquitos and ticks."Public health risks will become more pronounced, with a significant potential for loss of life and strain on health systems," the report noted.Among the natural disasters and environmental crises we could face as temperatures rise are more frequent category 4 and 5 cyclones, large hail on the east coast and an increased risk of bushfires in forested areas.Dangerous fire weather days are projected to become more frequent in southern and eastern areas too.The assessment also noted 63 "nationally significant" climate risks.These include threats to Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, risks to infrastructure, mental health impacts and loss of animal species.Minister for Climate Change and Energy Chris Bowen said the report made it clear that vulnerable Australians in rural communities will bear the brunt of climate change."Whether it be cropping, cattle sheep, fisheries… the report makes clear that Australia's regional areas will be big losers from climate change," Bowen said."We are living [through] climate change now, it's no longer a forecast, projection, or prediction."It is a lived reality. It is too late to avoid any impact now. But it's not too late to avoid the worst of the impacts."The financial impact of climate change in Australia is predicted to be astronomical.Losses in property value could soar to $611 billion by 2050 and may reach $770 billion by 2090.Disaster costs for each state and territory for flood, bushfire, storm surge and tropical cyclones for a moderate emissions scenario (+1.5 degrees ) could reach an annual cost of $40.3 billion by 2050 too.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Mass power outages, severe weather warnings as destructive winds pick up
clusters.neutral_headline: Destructive Winds Cause Power Outages in Several Areas

items.title: Mass power outages, severe weather warnings as destructive winds pick up
items.standfirst: A severe weather warning for damaging wind gusts is in place for residents in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, the ACT and southern parts of NSW.
items.content: The welcome burst of springtime sun has brought with it gale-force winds to five Australian states and territories, triggering mass power outages for thousands.A severe weather warning for damaging wind gusts is in place for residents in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, the ACT and southern parts of NSW.Wind gusts reaching up to 90km/h have ripped off a roof from a home in north-east Melbourne, while the airport has recorded the strongest winds of more than 100km/h.READ MORE: These siblings started a business with a few hundred bucks. It's made $20 millionThe wind also brought down what appeared to be a corrugated roof on a road in Fawkner, north Melbourne. The SES said it is responding to more than 500 incidents across the city. Train lines are also impacted as the ferocious winds damaged cabling and ripped up power lines . Thousands of residents in Melbourne and greater Victoria are without power this afternoon after a surge in wind gusts.Extreme weather conditions have caused unexpected power outages for more than 3000 people across the city.The surge of warm air has whipped up a windy frenzy before a cold front which is due to arrive tomorrow, Weatherzone reports.Power outages also impacted thousands of people in Tasmania earlier today after wind gusts topping 102km/h were recorded in Hobart. Despite the windy conditions, it will remain a sunny one for the rest of today.READ MORE: Teacher who beat cancer killed in tragic jet ski accidentWarmer weather for most of the country Springtime sun will wash across much of the land early this week in a break from repeated, successive cold fronts.Sydney is set for a top of 26 degrees today with sunny skies, rising towards 28 tomorrow, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.Temperatures will sway between low and high 20s for the rest of the week, with possible showers on Friday and Saturday.READ MORE: 'Note' left by Charlie Kirk shooting suspect under investigation Melbourne today has a top of 24 degrees, with the possibility of a late shower.After today, temperatures in the Victorian capital will dip again, however, and rain will remain a possibility throughout the week.A sunny Brisbane will peak at 25 today, but Wednesday is set to be the hottest day of the week with a top of 30 degrees.READ MORE: Car mounts footpath, hits boy in alleged hit and run in Melbourne There are possible showers forecast toward the end of the week. Adelaide is running counter to most capitals with rain forecast throughout the week, but temperatures will still top out at 25 today, before plummeting back to 17 degrees tomorrow.Hobart in Tasmania will top at 23 degrees today, but temperatures are set to remain below 20 for the rest of the week.READ MORE: Rapper and alleged underworld member the target of Sydney shooting Canberra also is seeing a high of 21 today compared to frostier temperatures and rain the rest of the week. Darwin will remain at tops of 33 or 34 degrees all week.Perth will reverse the trend of most capitals, starting out the week chilly and rainy with a top of 17 degrees today.However, by the end of the week the WA capital has sunny tops of 26 degrees predicted. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Family seeks answers after Gold Coast mum stabbed, burnt to death
clusters.neutral_headline: Family Seeks Answers in Gold Coast Murder Case

items.title: Family seeks answers after Gold Coast mum stabbed, burnt to death
items.standfirst: Kelly Wilkinson was accused of "cop shopping" by Queensland Police who did not act on her complaints days before her badly burnt body was found outside her Gold Coast home, a pre-inquest conference was told.
items.content: The family of a mother stabbed and set alight by her estranged husband are seeking answers after evidence emerged of police dismissing her domestic violence complaints.Kelly Wilkinson was accused of "cop shopping" by Queensland Police who did not act on her complaints days before her badly burnt body was found outside her Gold Coast home, a pre-inquest conference was told.Wilkinson, a 27-year-old mother-of-three, was repeatedly stabbed, doused with petrol and set on fire by Brian Earl Johnston at her Arundel home on April 20, 2021.READ MORE: Aussies staring down the barrel of looming $770 billion catastropheJohnston had been subject to a domestic violence order and was on bail, accused of sexually assaulting Wilkinson, when he murdered her.Wilkinson's family said they wanted to learn details about the police review into the handling of her domestic violence case at an upcoming inquest into her death.Wilkinson's sister Danielle Carroll said police review details had so far been kept hidden from the family."We are very interested to see what's in it," she said outside Southport Coroners Court after the pre-inquest conference today."There's a lot we have not been exposed to yet. There is still a lot for our family to process and go through."Carroll said she was seeking closure at the inquest, the final stage of a series of court proceedings."There's still a lot of information we don't know," she said."Hopefully we can learn something and move forward and make the world a bit safer for other victims."READ MORE: What do we know about Charlie Kirk's alleged killer?Queensland Deputy State Coroner Stephanie Gallagher today heard Wilkinson told a domestic violence prevention centre she was fearful of Johnston because he had military training and had threatened to kill her many times.Counsel assisting Bernhard Berger told the pre-inquest conference police had not acted when Wilkinson complained nine days before her death about Johnston allegedly breaching a domestic violence protection order by contacting her."Records will reveal that the (Southport Police Station) officer has concluded the file with a comment that is quite critical of Kelly," Berger said."He comments 'it appears she is cop shopping to get the outcome she wants'."Gallagher heard Wilkinson, assessed by the prevention centre as facing a high risk of violence, had earlier complained about protection order breaches at Runaway Bay Police Station.Berger said the officers' actions at the stations were initially upheld by a police review.One week later, Johnston, a former US Marine, entered Wilkinson's home wearing black clothing and a black mask while carrying a backpack with a hatchet, duct tape, zip ties and sedatives.Wilkinson's body was found outside her home with Johnston located nearby by police after he collapsed and suffered burns.Johnston was jailed for life in March 2024 after pleading guilty to murder.Berger told Gallagher the inquest also proposed to look into whether the police response to domestic violence complaints about Johnston were in accordance with procedures and policies."(The second issue) is whether the Queensland Police Service has made appropriate changes to training, policies and procedures to address any shortcomings identified in respect of domestic violence," he said.Queensland Police solicitor Tahlia Boettcher did not speak at the pre-inquest conference today.Gallagher adjourned the matter for a three-day inquest to start on a date to be determined.Support is available from the National Sexual Assault, Domestic and Family Violence Counselling Service at 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).Help is available from the Men's Referral Service on 1300 766 491.
